fields.headline: In brief
fields.bodyText: Former New Zealand premier dies Former New Zealand Prime Minister David Lange, 63, has died after complications of renal failure. A pugnacious and witty former Methodist lay preacher who spent five turbulent years as the country's premier from 1984, he was taken to hospital last month and had his right leg amputated after a complication of diabetes. Schröeder says no to force against Iran German Chancellor Gerhard Schröeder rejected the threat of military force against Iran yesterday, hours after President Bush said he would consider it as a last resort to press Tehran to give up its nuclear programme. Schröeder told an election rally in Hanover that the threat of force was not acceptable. Schroeder said he was 'worried about developments' in Iran, but would pursue negotiations. Mass bee attack An 83-year-old Texan woman is in intensive care after being stung by bees 400 times. The woman was attacked on Friday by bees coming from a storage building outside her home. A handyman sprayed her with water until the bees turned on him. He ran and called emergency services. Firefighters found the woman unconscious in the street. Indonesian peace deal The Indonesian government and Aceh rebels sent representatives to Finland yesterday to sign a peace agreement aimed at ending the 29-year conflict that has killed 15,000 people in the tsunami-ravaged province. The pact will allow reconstruction aid for tsunami victims. A previous truce ended after six months in 2003, when the Indonesian army expelled foreign observers, declared martial law, arrested rebel negotiators and mounted an offensive in which 3,000 people died. Uganda warns press The Ugandan government announced yesterday it would take action against any journalist who endangers national security in the name of press freedom or human rights. The statement came a day after the government charged a journalist with sedition for comments about the crash that killed Sudanese Vice President John Garang.
